user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl(OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, OS_SocketDomain_t Domain)
{
    sa_family_t             sa_family;
    socklen_t               addrlen;
    OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    memset(Addr, 0, sizeof(OS_SockAddr_t));
    Accessor = (OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Domain)
    {
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET:
            sa_family = AF_INET;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case OS_SocketDomain_INET6:
            sa_family = AF_INET6;
            addrlen   = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            sa_family = 0;
            addrlen   = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (addrlen == 0)
    {
        return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    Addr->ActualLength     = OSAL_SIZE_C(addrlen);
    Accessor->sa.sa_family = sa_family;

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketAddrInit_Impl:
typedef enum
{
    OS_SocketDomain_INVALID, /**< @brief Invalid */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET,    /**< @brief IPv4 address family, most commonly used) */
    OS_SocketDomain_INET6,   /**< @brief IPv6 address family, depends on OS/network stack support */
    OS_SocketDomain_MAX      /**< @brief Maximum */
} OS_SocketDomain_t
...
#define OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6 
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rest of the function does not present obvious unreachable code given the provided symbols: the initial memset and Accessor assignment are executed unconditionally and are used later; the OS_SocketDomain_INET case (sa_family = AF_INET; addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in); break;) is a reachable switch arm; the final assignments to Addr->ActualLength and Accessor->sa.sa_family and the return OS_SUCCESS are reachable when addrlen != 0. There are no trailing statements after an unconditional return, no statements following a jump that would be statically impossible to reach, and no other conditional compilation blocks in this function that would render code permanently excluded in the supplied configuration. Therefore only the listed fragments warrant further investigation for potential unreachable-code issues (the IPv6 conditional block depending on the macro and the default/addrlen==0 handling which may or may not be reachable across build/configurations).
